Constructs an Embedding layer that can be used in the graph. :param * num_embedding_lookups: Int (positive) - The number of embedding lookups to perform for each token. :param * lookup_size: Int (positive) - How many consutive values to select as part of the embedding for each embedding lookup. :param * log_embedding_block_size: Int (positive) The log base 2 of the total size of the embedding block.

class thirdai.bolt.nn.FullyConnected

Bases: Node

__init__(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

  1. __init__(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.FullyConnected, dim: int, activation: str) -> None

Constructs a dense FullyConnectedLayer object. :param * dim: Int (positive) - The dimension of the layer. :param * activation: String specifying the activation function to use, no restrictions on case - We support five activation functions: ReLU, Softmax, Tanh, Sigmoid, and Linear.

  1. __init__(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.FullyConnected, dim: int, sparsity: float, activation: str) -> None

Constructs a sparse FullyConnectedLayer object with sampling parameters autotuned. :param * dim: Int (positive) - The dimension of the layer. :param * sparsity: Float - What fraction of nuerons to activate during training and sparse inference. :param * activation: String specifying the activation function to use, no restrictions on case - We support five activation functions: ReLU, Softmax, Tanh, Sigmoid, and Linear.

  1. __init__(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.FullyConnected, dim: int, sparsity: float, activation: str, sampling_config: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.SamplingConfig) -> None

Constructs a sparse FullyConnectedLayer object. :param * dim: Int (positive) - The dimension of the layer. :param * sparsity: Float - What fraction of nuerons to activate during training and sparse inference. :param * activation: String specifying the activation function to use, no restrictions on case - We support five activation functions: ReLU, Softmax, Tanh, Sigmoid, and Linear. :param * sampling_config: :type * sampling_config: SamplingConfig

class thirdai.bolt.nn.Model

__init__(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

Constructs a bolt model from a layer graph. :param * inputs: :type * inputs: List[Node] :param * output: :type * output: Node

  1. __init__(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Model, inputs: List[thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Input], output: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Node) -> None

Constructs a bolt model from a layer graph. :param * inputs: :type * inputs: List[InputNode] :param * inputs: :type * inputs: List[TokenInput] :param * output: :type * output: Node

compile(loss: thirdai::bolt::LossFunction, print_when_done: bool = True) → None

Compiles the graph for the given loss function. In this step the order in which to compute the layers is determined and various checks are preformed to ensure the model architecture is correct.

evaluate(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

  1. evaluate(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Model, test_data: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, test_labels: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, eval_config: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.EvalConfig) -> tuple

  2. evaluate(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Model, test_data: List[thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset], test_labels: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, eval_config: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.EvalConfig) -> tuple

Predicts the output given the input vectors and evaluates the predictions based on the given metrics. :param * test_data: PyObject - Test data, in the same one of 3 formats as accepted by the train method (a BoltDataset, a dense numpy array, or a tuple of dense numpy arrays representing a sparse dataset) :param * test_labels: PyObject - Test labels, in the same format as test_data. This can also additionally be passed as None, in which case no metrics can be computed. :param * eval_config: EvalConfig - the additional prediction parameters. See the EvalConfig documentation above.

Returns a tuple, where the first element is a mapping from metric names to their values. The second element, the output activation matrix, is only present if dont_return_activations was not called. The third element, the active neuron matrix, is only present if we are returning activations AND the ouptut is sparse.

explain_prediction(input_data: List[dataset.BoltVector]) → tuple
explains why this model predicted the output with respect to input vector features.Arguments:

  • input_data: A single input sample. Returns a tuple consists of (0) optional, it only returns the corresponding indices for sparse inputs. and (1) list of values whichcorresponds to the features in input vector.

explain_required_label(input_data: List[dataset.BoltVector], neuron_to_explain: int) → tuple
explains how the input vector values should change so that model predicts the desired label.Arguments:

  • input_data: A single input sample. * neuron_to_explain: desired label user wants model to predict. Returns a tuple consists of (0) optional, it only returns the corresponding indices for sparse inputs. and (1) list of values whichtells how each feature should change in the input vector.

freeze_hash_tables(insert_labels_if_not_found: bool = True) → None

Prevents updates to hash tables in the model. If you plan to use sparse inference, you may get a significant performance improvement if you call this one or two epochs before you finish training. Otherwise you should not call this method. If insert_labels_if_not_found is true then if the output layer is sparse it will insert the training labels into the hash hash tables if they are not found for a given input.

get_input_confidence(input_data: List[dataset.BoltVector]) → tuple
gets some confidence values for the input vector, high the confidence more important the input feature for the model to predict.Arguments:

  • input_data: A single input sample. Returns a tuple consists of (0) optional, it only returns the corresponding indices for sparse inputs. and (1) list of confidence values which tells how much important each feature in the input vector.

get_input_gradients_single(input_data: List[dataset.BoltVector], explain_prediction_using_highest_activation: bool = True, neuron_to_explain: Optional[int] = None) → tuple
Get the values of input gradients when back propagate label with the highest activation or second highest activation or with the required label.Arguments:

  • input_data: The input is single input sample. * explain_prediction_using_highest_activation: Boolean, if set to True, gives gradients correspond to highest activation, Otherwise gives gradients corresponds to second highest activation. * neuron_to_explain: Optional, expected label for input vector, if it is provided then model gives gradients corresponds to that label. Returns a tuple consists of (0) optional, it only returns the corresponding indices for sparse inputs. and (1) list of gradients corresponds to the input vector.

get_layer(layer_name: str) → bolt.nn.Node

Looks up a layer (node) of the network by using the layer’s assigned name. As such, must be called after compile. You can determine which layer is which by printing a graph summary. Possible operations to perform on the returned object include setting layer sparsity, freezing weights, or saving to a file

static load(filename: str) → bolt.nn.Model
nodes() → List[bolt.nn.Node]

Returns a list of all Nodes that make up the graph in traversal order. This list is guaranetted to be static after a model is compiled.

save(filename: str) → None
summary(print: bool = True, detailed: bool = False) → str

Returns a summary of the network. :param * print: boolean. Optional, default True. When specified to “True”, summary will print the network summary in addition to returning it. * detailed: boolean. Optional, default False. When specified to “True”, summary will additionally return/print sampling config details for each layer in the network.

train(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

  1. train(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Model, train_data: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, train_labels: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, train_config: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.TrainConfig) -> Dict[str, List[float]]

  2. train(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.Model, train_data: List[thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset], train_labels: thirdai._thirdai.dataset.BoltDataset, train_config: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.TrainConfig) -> Dict[str, List[float]]

Trains the network on the given training data and labels with the given training config.

Parameters

  • train_data (List[BoltDataset] or BoltDataset) – The data to train the model with. There should be exactly one BoltDataset for each Input node in the Bolt model, and each BoltDataset should have the same total number of vectors and the same batch size. The batch size for training is the batch size of the passed in BoltDatasets (you can specify this batch size when loading or creating a BoltDataset).

  • train_labels (BoltDataset) – The labels to use as ground truth during training. There should be the same number of total vectors and the same batch size in this BoltDataset as in the train_data list.

  • train_config (TrainConfig) – The object describing all other training configuration details. See the TrainConfig documentation for more information as to possible options. This includes the number of epochs to train for, the verbosity of the training, the learning rate, and so much more!

Returns

A dictionary from metric name to a list of the value of that metric for each epoch (this also always includes an entry for ‘epoch_times’). The metrics that are returned are the metrics requested in the TrainConfig.

Return type

Dict[Str, List[float]]

Notes

Sparse bolt training was originally based off of SLIDE. See 1 for more details

References

1

“SLIDE : In Defense of Smart Algorithms over Hardware Acceleration for Large-Scale Deep Learning Systems” https://arxiv.org/pdf/1903.03129.pdf.

Examples

>>> train_config = (
        bolt.graph.TrainConfig.make(learning_rate=0.001, epochs=3)
        .with_metrics(["categorical_accuracy"])
    )
>>> metrics = model.train(
        train_data=train_data, train_labels=train_labels, train_config=train_config
    )
>>> print(metrics)
{'epoch_times': [1.7, 3.4, 5.2], 'categorical_accuracy': [0.4665, 0.887, 0.9685]}

That’s all for now, folks! More docs coming soon :)

class thirdai.bolt.nn.ParameterReference

Bases: pybind11_object

compress(compression_scheme: str, compression_density: float, seed_for_hashing: int, sample_population_size: int) → numpy.ndarray[numpy.int8]

Returns a char array representing a compressed vector. sample_population_size is the number of random samples you take for estimating a threshold for dragon compression or the number of sketches needed for count_sketch

static concat(compressed_vectors: object) → numpy.ndarray[numpy.int8]

Takes in a list of compressed vector objects and returns a concatenated compressed vector object. Concatenation is non-lossy in nature but comes at the cost of a higher memory footprint. Note: Only concatenate compressed vectors of the same type with the same hyperparamters.

copy() → numpy.ndarray[numpy.float32]

Returns a copy of the parameters held in the ParameterReference as a numpy array.

get() → numpy.ndarray[numpy.float32]

Returns a numpy array which shadows the parameters held in the ParameterReference and acts as a reference to them, modifying this array will modify the parameters.

set(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

  1. set(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.ParameterReference, new_params: numpy.ndarray[numpy.int8]) -> None

Takes a char array as input that represents a compressed vector and decompresses and copies into the ParameterReference object.

  1. set(self: thirdai._thirdai.bolt.nn.ParameterReference, new_params: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float32]) -> None

Takes a numpy array of floats as input and copies its contents into the parameters held in the parameter reference object.
